01 Brief

This presentation looks at patterns in current diversity hires at Adobe and selected competitors. The goal is to assess where Adobe currently stands in terms of diversity in order to set benchmarks and determine what possible directions for improvement the data suggests.

In this analysis, 18 companies have been selected to compare Adobe to: Box, Docusign, Dropbox, episerver, IBM, Microsoft, OKTA, Oracle, Pegasystems, Salesforce, SAP, ServiceNow, Sitecore, Splunk, Tableau, Twilio, Workday, Zendesk.

02 Competitors' diversity benchmark

In terms of overall diversity, Adobe sits about halfway through the ranking, in the 9th position out of 19 companies. It is estimated that around 43% of the workforce in the sample can be considered diverse either in terms of gender or ethnicity.

In terms of gender diversity, 36% of the Adobe employees in the sample have been classified as female, with Box (50%), Twilio (43%) and Zendesk (41%) being the companies closer to a gender-balanced workforce.

In terms of ethnic diversity, 12% of the Adobe employees in the sample have been classified as ethnically diverse, a ratio comparable to that of bigger companies like Microsoft, Salesforce and SAP. Like for gender diversity, Box ranks as the most ethnically-diverse company, with 16%.

Ethnic and gender diversity at Adobe and competing companies

The following chart shows each company's share of female diverse, male diverse, female non-diverse and male non-diverse employees.

Adobe estimated to be in around the median for both gender and ethnic diversity of its sales workforce

The following chart shows how Adobe's current workforce composition compares with others. Companies in the upper left corner are more diverse, having the an above average share of both female workforce and ethnically diverse workforce. Company bubbles are sized according to workforce size in the sample.

Ethnic diversity at Adobe and competing companies

The following chart shows the share of different ethnic minorities among each company's workforce. It can be used to address specific gaps in hiring ethnically diverse talent by benchmarking with industry competitors.

While Adobe can be considered in the median range for overall employee diversity, an analysis of what the numbers look like at different seniority levels shows how Adobe falls behind in keeping a consistent rate of female talent throughout the career ladder. It is worth noting that the numbers on the total junior employees are in most cases very small, and thus might not be very representative of the category. Because of this, it is more accurate to evaluate the drop between intermediate and senior employees, which have more comparable sample sizes.

As seniority level increases, the share of female talent represented in a company's workforce decreases. This pattern is present in almost all of the companies considered, but the drop is particularly stark for Adobe, which goes from being the 6th company for share of intermediate female employees to being the 13th for share of senior female employees.

A similar pattern is also found when considering ethnically diverse talent, with Adobe having 15% ethnically diverse intermediate employees in the sample and 10% ethnically diverse seniors, dropping from the 4th most diverse company at intermediate level to 13th at senior level.

At Adobe, less than 1 every 3 senior employees is female.

The following chart shows how none of the selected companies is close to a 50% female senior workforce, and that the share of female employees drops as seniority level rises. The only exception to this are DocuSign and Episerver.
Please be mindful of sample sizes (visible in the tooltip on hover) when evaluating numbers referring to junior level.

Gender representation at different levels of seniority

The following chart shows how far each company is from being gender balanced in each level of seniority.

Ethnic diversity drops at increasing levels of seniority.

The following chart shows how, with a few exceptions, the share of ethically diverse employees drops as seniority level rises.
Please be mindful of sample sizes (visible in the tooltip on hover) when evaluating numbers referring to junior level.

03 Sources of diverse talent

From the analysis of a dataset of about 90K software sales professionals located in France, Germany and United Kingdom, we identified cities currently hosting diverse talent in which Adobe has little or no presence in terms of employees.

Some cities that stand out are Berlin, Walldorf, and Frankfurt in Germany; and Reading in the UK: these cities are hosting more diverse talent in comparison to Adobe's talent located here.

Universities attended by the employees considered in the sample can suggest institutions were recruiting is more likely to result in the hire of diverse talent. There is no university being a significant feeder of female talent, while some British universities seem more likely to provide ethnically diverse talent than others.

Top cities currently hosting female and ethnically diverse talent.

The following chart shows the top cities hosting female talent (horizontal axis) and ethnically diverse talent (vertical axis). Cities towards the top-right corner are thus the ones hosting overall most diverse talent. Bubbles are sized by the number of Adobe's current employees located there, and bubbles in red indicate cities with no Adobe employees in the sample: small or red bubbles located in areas of the chart with highly diverse talent thus indicate cities that could serve as a source of diverse hires.Chart contains only cities with more than 20 female or ethnically diverse hires.

Top universities for diverse talent

The chart shows the top 50 universities that have provided higher numbers of diverse workforce to the talent pool - according to the filter chosen. On the red part of the diagram, universities missing from Adobe's talent pool. The dataset has been filtered to look only at universities cited by at least 50 people in the selected talent pool.

Past employment history can reveal which are the companies passing most diverse talent to Adobe or its competitors.

Such analysis reveals that IBM, Oracle and HP have seeded most female talent to the selected companies. Looking only at Adobe, its female employees have previously worked mostly at Oracle, Microsoft and Neolene. The same companies are also among major feeders for ethnically diverse talent, along with Accenture.

Top companies for female talent

The chart shows the companies which historically* have fed most female talent to Adobe or its competitors.
*The time frame considered is last 6 employments and only flows with 15+ employees are considered

Top companies for ethnically diverse talent

The chart shows the companies which historically* have fed most ethnically diverse talent to Adobe or its competitors.
*The time frame considered is last 6 employments and only flows with 10+ employees are considered

04 Key takeaways

01

    COMPETITORS' & BENCHMARK

  • Adobe is overall in line with competitors' median diversity. There are however some companies that fare better, in particular smaller companies like Twilio, Tableau and Box.
  • There is the need to increase diversity at senior level. While for ethnically diverse talent the relative drop at senior level is similar in size to that of competitors, for gender diversity it is bigger as the share of female employees drops of about 20 percentage points going from junior to senior level.

02

    CURRENT LOCATION

  • Current location can suggest possible hiring hotspots for diverse talent. In particular, German cities like Berlin, Walldorf, and Frankfurt in Germany, or British cities like Reading, seem to have a high rate of diverse talent while also being places where Adobe has little or zero employees in the sample considered. This matter needs to be investigated further to rule out bias in the data that could influence the results - like the presence of big corporate headquarters in otherwise small cities.

03

    UNIVERITIES & EDUCATION

  • Universities attended by the employees considered can suggest institutions were recruiting is more likely to result in the hire of diverse talent. There is no university being a significant feeder of female talent. The most common (Essec Business School, The Open University, The Chartered Institute Of Marketing, Bournemouth University and University Of Portsmouth) have been cited by at most 1.5% of the female talent pool.
  • As for ethnically diverse talent, the most frequent universities are all in the United Kingdom: Brunel University London (cited by 3% of the ethnically diverse talent pool) , Kingston University (2%) and Aston University (2%). A challenge with this data is that some deeper cleaning is needed to standardize names and perhaps bring more accurate insights.

04

    PAST EMPLOYMENT

  • Past employment history can reveal if there are companies that have been feeding diverse talent to Adobe or its competitors at a particularly high rate.
  • In terms of both female and ethnically diverse talent, IBM, Oracle and HP are the companies appearing most, along with Accenuture specifically for ethcically diverse employees.

Thank you
